title: UK Athletics performance director Neil Black could resign in wake of Alberto Salazar scandal
text:
There are growing doubts over Neil Black's future as the performance director of UK Athletics after he refused to rule out resigning in the wake of the Alberto Salazar scandal.

Black will speak in the coming days with UKA CEO Zara Hyde and chairman Chris Clark to deal with the fallout of Salazar's four-year drugs ban and the implications for an organisation that in 2015 cleared the disgraced coach to work with Mo Farah.

That review, which gave Farah the green light to stay at the Nike Oregon Project despite hugely damaging revelations in a Panorama documentary, has left Black facing serious questions over his judgement.

UK Athletics Performance Director Neil Black could resign in the wake of the Alberto Salazar scandal. Salazar, former coach to British runner Mo Farah, has been banned for four years

Salazar, who coached Farah between 2011 and 2017, was banned for four years last week

Neither will it be favourable that his team missed their medal target at the World Championships.

Speaking publicly for the first time since last Monday's ruling on Salazar, who coached Farah between 2011 and 2017, Black was non-committal on whether he would survive the aftermath.

Asked directly if he would resign, he said: 'Travelling home I'll be reviewing all the information. The board will obviously review all the information and the first person I'll speak to will be the chair Chris Clark.

'We will go through it in detail and that's the point I personally will begin to think about my understanding of it, the implications and how I feel about it.'

When pushed to clarify if he would resign, he said: 'I'm not able to answer with any more detail.'

While Black wants to stay through the Tokyo Olympics next year, he could face internal and external pressure to go after his emphatic backing of Salazar in the past, which previously included hiring him as a consultant to UKA and once describing him as a 'genius'.

With UKA having said in 2015 that they had 'no concerns' about Salazar's coaching relationship with their prime medal winner, their board and performance oversight committee is currently reviewing the full findings of the US Anti-Doping Agency investigation.

Salazar (centre) pictured with Mo Farah (right) and American athlete Galen Rupp in 2012

There is no suggestion of any wrongdoing by Black or Farah, who has never failed a drugs test.

During USADA's four-year investigation, they alleged Salazar's doctor, Dr Jeffrey Brown – also banned for four years – was complicit with Salazar in 'prescribing excessive and dangerous levels of prescription vitamin D and thyroid medicines to NOP athletes, hoping these prescriptions would increase testosterone levels'.

Owing to the links between Salazar, Black and UKA's head of endurance Barry Fudge, Black was asked if UKA had incorporated similar methods and received medications that were not medically necessary.

Black said: 'I am very, very sure that no British athletes have been involved in any of those processes, I am very sure about that.'

Asked specifically if thyroid medication had been used in that manner, he said: 'Certainly to the best of my knowledge, no British athlete has ever taken thyroid medication when it wasn't required. It was obviously confidential information but the only time any medication was used and so on was for a medical reason, without any question.'

Pressure has also mounted on Black after British athletes failed to achieve their medal target

The renewed focus on Farah's work with Salazar – a period in which he won all four of his Olympic gold medals – comes ahead of Sunday's Chicago marathon. Black will fly to the US this week to support Farah's preparations.

Black, who has not yet read the full USADA report, said: 'Nothing at all has changed in terms of my belief regarding Mo Farah. I think it is important to repeat that the British Athletics and the medical and support teams were always the people who were always on top of, and managing and directing the care of Mo Farah, so we have no concerns.'

The scrutiny on Black follows the failure of his team to hit their UK Sport medal target of seven to nine, with only five won in Doha. Their placings between fourth and eighth also fell from 19 at London 2017 to 11.

Black said: 'There's a lot to feel really good about. But the reality is the medal tally is not that which we would have wanted.

'It could be better, it should be better. We'll obviously be talking with UK Sport. Our relationship with UK Sport is really positive. It's a working together, it's reviewing, planning, what have we learnt, what are we going to do about it, how do we convert the nearlies into medals.'
description: RIATH AL-SAMARRAI IN DOHA: There are growing doubts over Neil Black's future as the performance director of UK Athletics after he refused to rule out resigning after the Alberto Salazar scandal.
